text: (light music)

- [Michael] Hello, my
name is Michael Bochynski
and I'm a senior technical program manager
at AWS Marketplace.

In this video, I'll be walking
you through new features

available today for AWS
Marketplace sellers,
local currency offers and disbursement,

and I'll show you how you
can add your bank accounts

and set disbursements
methods in local currencies.
Previously, AWS Marketplace sellers
can only sell in US dollars.

Buyers can choose to pay
invoices in local currencies.

However, the invoicing amount
from USD to local currencies

is only visible to the buyer
at the time of invoice receipt.
For deals with future invoicing dates,
and especially multi-year transactions,
buyers face the FX variability risk.
To address these points of friction,
we are rolling out the changes in 2024
that I will dive into next.

Let's go over the scope
of what's being launched
in the remainder of 2024.

In 2024, we'll be enabling
AWS Marketplace sellers

to create offers in four
additional non-USD currencies

and receive disbursements
in local bank accounts.
More specifically, with this launch,

sellers will be able to
create private offers
using the euro, British pound,
Japanese yen, and the Australian dollar.

Sellers will be able to
receive disbursements
in that same currency.

Next, sellers will be able
to receive disbursements

in local bank accounts
in eligible jurisdictions
like the EU, UK, Australia, and Japan
to receive disbursements.
And finally, buyers will be able

to procure software and
services from AWS Marketplace

without the current foreign
exchange variability risk
since they can now be invoiced
in the same currency as the seller.
Now let's deep dive into how you can use

your local bank accounts
to receive disbursements.
You can use one bank account

to receive disbursements
in multiple currencies,
or use multiple bank accounts
and set up with a separate currency.

If you want to use a bank
account located in the UK,
you must complete the Know-Your-Customer,
the KYC process for AWS EMEA.

For disbursements, US ACH
accounts and Hyperwallet
can only receive disbursements in USD.

UK bank accounts can only
receive disbursements

in Euro and GBP from sales
invoiced by AWS EMEA.
If you want to learn more

on how to create private
offers in non-USD,

please watch our next
video that guides you
through the offer creation process.
Private offer with contract-only pricing.
You can only transact private offers

with contract-only pricing
directly in non-USD.
For example, SaaS contract, AMI contract,
and Professional Services.
CPPO pricing.

ISV sets the currency in
the resale authorization,
and Channel Partner will need to create
a CPPO in the same currency.

You will receive disbursements
in the same currency
as defined in the private offer.

Now I will show you how you can
add your local bank accounts
and set the disbursement method
inside the AWS Management portal.

Log into your AWS
Marketplace seller account,
navigate to the settings tab,
and click on payment information.

Here you can now select
to add SWIFT bank account.
If you choose to use SWIFT account,

you will need to provide
bank account details
and billing address.

Business Identifier Code,
also known as SWIFT code,
is a code with eight to 11 characters

that identifies banks and
financial institutions globally.
You can find your BIC in multiple ways,
including asking your bank directly.

Billing address is the
billing contact information
used to verify the billing address
associated with your payment method.
This contact is also used for any billing
or payment related communication.
Please note that using SWIFT accounts

may incur costs for
incoming disbursements.
Reach out to your bank for more details.
Once you have added your bank accounts,
you can now link a currency
to this bank account disbursement method.
You can use one bank account
or multiple ones to receive disbursements.
If you want to use one bank account

to receive disbursements in
all supported currencies,
please check with your bank directly

on what currencies can be
dispersed into your bank account.
(light music)
